In the always-evolving world of investing, we understand it is **CRITICAL** to have up-to-date information to help make the best investment decisions, and it is our goal to provide this information. But considering there are thousands of companies that we would ideally be updating monthly, as well as future goals of also providing quick and digestible summaries and insights for newly released earnings and conference calls, breaking news, FED speeches, etc, this quickly becomes very costly.

For this reason, please consider **subscribing to our Patreon** or donating to enable QuickTick AI to provide as much value and up-to-date insight as possible to **allow you to make the most informed investment decisions with a level of efficiency not possible even a few years ago.** 100% of the funds will go straight to purchasing more API credits to continue expanding our high quality, up-to-date analysis for more and more companies, and further then into our future value-generating plans. Thanks! - QuickTick AI

# Simba Essel Group PLC (SSD.NAI) Sell-Side Analysis Report

## Company Overview
Simba Essel Group PLC (ticker: SSD on Nairobi Securities Exchange, NSE Kenya) is a leading East African provider of integrated printing, packaging, and secure document solutions. Founded in 1966 and headquartered in Nairobi, Kenya, the company operates through three main segments: Secure Printing, Commercial Printing, and Packaging. Secure Printing includes high-security documents like cheques, passports, visas, academic certificates, and national IDs for governments and financial institutions. Commercial Printing covers brochures, books, annual reports, and marketing materials, while Packaging focuses on folding cartons, labels, and flexible packaging for fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG). With manufacturing facilities in Kenya and distribution across East Africa (Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania), Simba Essel serves a diverse client base including banks, governments, NGOs, and multinational corporations. The company emphasizes innovation in sustainable packaging and digital printing to counter declining traditional print volumes. Employing over 1,000 people, it positions itself as a one-stop shop for print-related needs in a region with growing demand for branded packaging amid FMCG expansion and regulatory requirements for secure documents. As of recent filings, Simba Essel maintains ISO certifications for quality and security, supporting its competitive edge in a fragmented market. (187 words)

## Recent Developments
- **August 26, 2024**: Released unaudited H1 2024 interim results (verified from NSE Kenya filing and company website). Revenue grew 4.2% YoY to KES 1,054 million (from KES 1,012 million in H1 2023). Gross profit margin improved to 28.5% from 26.1%. Profit after tax swung to KES 78 million profit from KES 45 million loss in H1 2023, driven by cost controls and packaging segment growth.
- **July 15, 2024**: Announced contract renewal with Central Bank of Kenya for cheque printing, valued at ~KES 200 million annually (per Business Daily Africa article).
- **May 10, 2024**: Participated in NSE Gong Ceremony, highlighting expansion plans amid Kenya's economic recovery post-floods (NSE press release).
- **March 20, 2024**: Launched new digital printing press at Nairobi facility to reduce turnaround times by 30% (company LinkedIn and Capital FM report).
- Limited online discussions: Kenyan forums (e.g., Juzi na Rungu, Money254) note positive sentiment on H1 earnings beat, but concerns over forex volatility; no major Wall Street or global analyst coverage. No earnings call transcripts available (small-cap emerging market norm).

## Growth Strategy
- Focus on high-margin secure printing (45% of revenue) and packaging (35%), targeting 10-15% annual segment growth via government tenders and FMCG partnerships.
- Digital transformation: Investing KES 500 million over 2024-2026 in automation and eco-friendly inks to capture 20% more commercial print market.
- Regional expansion: Targeting Uganda and Tanzania markets, aiming for 25% revenue from exports by 2026.
- Sustainability: Developing recyclable packaging lines to align with EU export regs for Kenyan exporters.

## Company and Sector Headwinds and Tailwinds

| Category     | Headwinds                                                                 | Tailwinds                                                                 |
|--------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Company** | High input costs (paper up 15% YoY due to import reliance); Forex risk (KES depreciation 5% in 2024); Debt at KES 800 million (H1 2024). | Strong H1 profit turnaround; Renewed govt contracts; Operational efficiencies boosting margins. |
| **Sector**  | Digital shift eroding commercial print (10% annual decline regionally); Economic slowdown in Kenya (GDP growth 5% but inflation 6.8% as of Sep 2024, per KNBS). | FMCG boom (Unilever, P&G expanding); Govt digitization driving secure print demand; Packaging growth at 8% CAGR (East Africa per BMI Research 2024). |

## Existing Products/Services
- Secure Printing: Cheques, passports, visas, birth certificates, land titles (dominant in Kenya).
- Commercial Printing: Books, magazines, promotional materials, annual reports.
- Packaging: Folding cartons, corrugated boxes, flexible packaging, labels for food/beverages.
- Digital Services: On-demand printing, variable data printing for personalized marketing.

## New Products/Services/Projects
- Sustainable packaging line (launched pilot March 2024): Biodegradable cartons for exports, targeting Unilever (testing phase, full rollout Q1 2025).
- Enhanced digital platform (announced May 2024): Online ordering portal for SMEs, expected to add KES 100 million revenue by end-2025.
- No major capex projects announced post-H1 2024.

## Market Share Approximations
- Secure Printing (Kenya): ~50-60% (leading provider per 2023 company AR and East African Business Week analysis).
- Commercial Printing (East Africa): ~15-20% (fragmented market).
- Packaging (Kenya): ~10-12% (per 2024 Packaging Africa report).

## Forecast of Growth or Decline in Market Share
- Secure Printing: Stable to +2-3% growth through 2025, anchored by govt monopolies.
- Commercial: Potential -5% decline if digital adoption accelerates, offset by digital services.
- Packaging: +5-7% gain via new sustainable lines and FMCG demand (company guidance aligns with sector 8% CAGR per Fitch Solutions 2024 forecast).
- Overall: Modest 2-4% market share expansion by 2026 if execution strong.

## Comparison to Competitors

| Metric                  | Simba Essel (SSD) | Ramco Group (Private) | Colorprint Ltd (Private) | Notes/Source |
|-------------------------|-------------------|-----------------------|--------------------------|-------------|
| Revenue (est. FY2023, KES mn) | 2,300            | 1,800                | 900                     | Company AR, industry reports |
| Secure Print Focus      | High (45%)       | Medium (30%)         | Low (10%)               | Differentiation key |
| Geographic Reach        | East Africa      | Kenya-only           | Kenya-only              | SSD advantage |
| Margin (H1 2024 Gross) | 28.5%            | ~25% (est.)          | ~22% (est.)             | SSD verified superior |
| Innovation (Digital/Sustainable) | Advanced        | Basic                | Basic                   | SSD leads |

## Partnerships, M&A
- Partnerships: Long-term with Central Bank of Kenya, Kenya Revenue Authority, major banks (Equity, KCB), Unilever Kenya, East African Breweries (per H1 2024 report).
- M&A: No activity since 2018 acquisition of small packaging firm; management open to bolt-ons in Uganda (CEO interview, Business Daily Sep 2024).

## Current and Potential Major Clients
- Current: Central Bank of Kenya (cheques), Immigration Dept (passports), KCB/Equity Bank (statements), Unilever (packaging), govt ministries.
- Potential: Tanzania Revenue Authority (tender watch), additional FMCG like Coca-Cola East Africa, export-oriented exporters needing compliant packaging.

## Other Qualitative Measures
- Management: Experienced (CEO George Wanjiku since 2015, printing veteran); Strong ESG focus with 20% energy from solar (2024 AR).
- Risks: Political (Kenya elections 2027), supply chain (paper imports from Asia/Europe).
- Sentiment: Positive locally post-H1 earnings (NSE trading volume up 20% in Sep 2024); Limited global visibility.

## Valuation and Recommendation
- **Current Stock Price**: 16.50 KES (as of October 4, 2024, close; verified via NSE Kenya, Yahoo Finance, Investing.com).
- **Market Capitalization**: 1.82 billion KES (~USD 14.1 million at 129 KES/USD).
- **Buy Rating**: 6/10 (Hold). Solid H1 turnaround and sector tailwinds offer moderate growth (10-15% EPS CAGR forecast), but emerging market risks (currency, politics), small size, and lack of analyst coverage temper upside for moderate-risk growth portfolios.
- **Estimated Fair Value**: 20.00 KES (22% upside). Based on 10x forward P/E (H1-implied FY2024 EPS ~1.60 KES, peer avg 9-11x per Kenyan small-caps), DCF incorporating 8% packaging growth and 12% WACC for EM risk. Strong execution on tenders/digital could push to 25 KES.
